Main_Event_Annotation: header: 2010–2011 China drought - 'The 2010–2011 China drought was a drought that began in late 2010 and impacted eight provinces...'
Hazards_Annotation: header: 2010–2011 China drought - 'The 2010–2011 China drought was a drought that began in late 2010...'
Time_Annotation: “The 2010–2011 China drought was a drought that began in late 2010…” (header: 2010–2011 China Drought); “The drought began as early as September 2010 in some regions.” (header: Cause)
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: “…impacted eight provinces in the northern part of the People's Republic of China (PRC).” (header: 2010–2011 China Drought)

Event_Names: November 2005 Central United States Tornado Outbreak
Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box: "Type: Tornado outbreak"
Hazards_Annotation: Derived from the Main_Event--Hazard association table referencing "Type: Tornado outbreak" in the Info_Box.
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: "Duration: November 27 - 28, 2005"; Header: "Tornado outbreak of November 27–28, 2005"; Article content: "On November 27 and 28, 2005..."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: "Areas affected: Kansas, Missouri, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama"

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Cyclone Monica, content: "Severe Tropical Cyclone Monica was the most intense tropical cyclone…"
Hazards_Annotation: Wind hazard from Header: Cyclone Monica, content: "…an area about 7,000 km2 (2,700 sq mi) was defoliated by Monica's high wind gusts."; Flood hazard from Header: Queensland, content: "Minor coastal flooding was also reported due to Monica." and Header: Northern Territory, content: "Flash flooding was reported throughout the Adelaide River basin…"
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Electra Fire (2022), content: "The Electra Fire was a wildfire that burned northeast of Mokelumne Hill..."
Hazards_Annotation: header: Electra Fire (2022), content: "The Electra Fire was a wildfire that burned northeast of Mokelumne Hill..."
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Date(s): July 4, 2022 (2022-07-04) - July 28, 2022 (2022-07-28)'. Also in the article header about the Electra Fire stating it started on July 4, 2022 and was contained on July 28, 2022.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Header: 'The Electra Fire was a wildfire... in Amador and Calaveras Counties, California', indicating it took place in the United States.

Main_Event_Annotation: [header: 2008 Queensland storms] The article describes these events as a series of three thunderstorms striking South East Queensland.
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from [header: First incident], “Winds reached 130 kilometres (81 mi)/h” | Flood from [header: Second incident], “The Inner City Bypass was flooded and forced to close” | Hail from [header: Third incident], “Hail was described as the size of golf balls”
Time_Annotation: header: 2008 Queensland storms, content: 'The first storm hit on 16 November 2008 and was followed by two further storms on 19 and 20 November.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: header: 2008 Queensland storms, content: 'The 2008 Queensland storms were a series of three thunderstorms that struck South East Queensland, Australia.'

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Typhoon Sepat, content: 'Typhoon Sepat ... was the eighth named tropical storm and the strongest tropical cyclone of the 2007 Pacific typhoon season...'
Hazards_Annotation: header: Philippines, content: 'On August 15, monsoon rains brought by Typhoon Sepat flooded and paralyzed traffic in Metro Manila.' | header: Mainland China, content: 'In Fujian Province, Sepat’s winds felled billboards and ripped roofs off houses...'
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Formed: August 12, 2007' and 'Dissipated: August 24, 2007'. Article: 'Sepat originated on August 11 …finally dissipated near Yunnan Province on August 24.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Philippines, Taiwan, China'. Article: '…that affected the Philippines and made landfall in Taiwan and Fujian.'

Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box (Type: Heat wave)
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box (Type: Heat wave)
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: “Start date: June 25, 2021 (2021-06-25) End date: July 7, 2021 (2021-07-07)”; header: 2021 Western North America heat wave, content: “The 2021 Western North America heat wave was an extreme heat wave that affected much of Western North America from late June through mid-July 2021.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: header: 2021 Western North America heat wave, content: “The heat wave affected Northern California, Idaho, Western Nevada, Oregon, and Washington in the United States, as well as British Columbia, Alberta, Manitoba, the Northwest Territories, Saskatchewan, and Yukon, all in Canada.”

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Hurricane Ophelia (2005), content: "Hurricane Ophelia was a long-lived tropical cyclone in September 2005..."
Hazards_Annotation: • Wind: Info_Box (Highest winds: 85 mph (140 km/h)) and multiple references in the article (e.g., “its eyewall scraped the coastline for two days”) • Flood: Hurricane Ophelia (2005), content: “Some coastal locales saw heavy rain… more than 15 in (380 mm)” • Lightning: Hurricane Ophelia (2005), North Carolina section, content: “...a fishing vessel was stranded… after being struck by lightning.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: header: 2017 West Bengal floods
Hazards_Annotation: header: 2017 West Bengal floods, content: “the Indian state of West Bengal was affected by severe flooding.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: Location: West Bengal and Jharkhand, India

Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box (Type: Heatwave)
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box (Type: Heatwave)
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Start date: 10 June 2022 (2022-06-10)' and 'End date: 12 September 2022 (2022-09-12)'. Also referenced in the article header '2022 European heatwaves' (e.g., 'From June to August 2022...' and noting a smaller heatwave on 12 September).
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Countries listed in the Info_Box: 'Andorra, Austria, Belgium, Croatia, Denmark...' and so on, plus mentions in the article under various headers (including dedicated sections for Iceland, Romania, Sweden, the Vatican, Guernsey, Jersey) and references to Cyprus in the context of excess deaths.

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Hurricane Agnes – “Agnes was the second tropical cyclone and first named storm of the 1972 Atlantic hurricane season.”
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box: “Highest winds: 85 mph (140 km/h)” and Header: Hurricane Agnes – “Damage was heaviest in Pennsylvania, mostly due to intense flooding.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: “Areas affected: Yucatan Peninsula, Western Cuba, East Coast of the United States (especially Pennsylvania), Atlantic Canada, Iceland, British Isles”

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Typhoon Alex (1987)
Hazards_Annotation: header: Impact and aftermath (e.g., “A 35-year-old man was crushed to death by a falling wall in Keelung due to strong winds...” and “... triggering flooding and landslides.”)
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Taiwan, central China, South Korea)

Main_Event_Annotation: From the header "Tropical Storm Ampil" in the article: "...was a tropical cyclone..."
Hazards_Annotation: Wind: Mentioned in the Info_Box ("Highest winds: 100 km/h") and under "Tropical Storm Ampil" header ("produced gusty winds..."); Flood: Under "Tropical Storm Ampil" header ("record-breaking flooding within the watershed of the Songhua River..."); Lightning: Under "Japan" header ("Moisture extending from Ampil also caused thunderstorms in Fukuoka...")
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box and article text mention weather impacts in the Ryukyu Islands (Japan) and East and Northeast China.

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: 'Dome Fire (2020)', content: 'The 2020 Dome Fire was a large and ecologically destructive wildfire in the Mojave National Preserve...'
Hazards_Annotation: Header: 'Dome Fire (2020)', content: 'The 2020 Dome Fire was a large and ecologically destructive wildfire in the Mojave National Preserve...'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: Location: San Bernardino County, California, United States

Main_Event_Annotation: From the 'Cyclone Luban' header content: “Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Luban was the third tropical cyclone to affect the Arabian Peninsula during the 2018 North Indian Ocean cyclone season...”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind: from the Info_Box (Highest winds: 155 km/h). Flood: from the 'Cyclone Luban' header content: “Upon moving ashore, Cyclone Luban produced flooding rains in Somalia, Oman, and Yemen.”
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: Formed: October 6, 2018 – Dissipated: October 15, 2018; header: Cyclone Luban, content: “Luban developed on October 6… before dissipating on October 15.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: Areas affected: Oman, Somalia, Yemen; header: Cyclone Luban, content: “Upon moving ashore, Cyclone Luban produced flooding rains in Somalia, Oman, and Yemen.”

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Palmer Fire – “The Palmer Fire was a wildfire in Beaumont, California in the United States.”
Hazards_Annotation: header: Palmer Fire – “The Palmer Fire was a wildfire in Beaumont, California in the United States.”
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: Date(s): September 2, 2017 (2017-09-02) - September 6, 2017 (2017-09-06). Also stated in the 'Palmer Fire' header content: The fire was reported on September 2, 2017, and was 100% contained by September 6, 2017.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: Location: Beaumont, California, United States. Also in the 'Palmer Fire' header content: The Palmer Fire was a wildfire in Beaumont, California in the United States.

Main_Event_Annotation: From the header "Tropical Storm Erika" in the article: "Tropical Storm Erika was one of the deadliest and most destructive natural disasters in Dominica..."
Hazards_Annotation: Wind: from Info_Box ("Highest winds: 50 mph (85 km/h)"); Flood: from header "Tropical Storm Erika" content ("...led to rainfall accumulations up to 33 in (850 mm)... triggered catastrophic floods."); Lightning: from header "Southeastern United States" content ("...lightning struck the Sally B. Mathis Elementary School...").
Time_Annotation: Info_Box (Formed: August 24, 2015, Dissipated: September 3, 2015). Also referenced in 'Meteorological history' section stating the system dissipated over Georgia on September 3, 2015.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Listed under Info_Box (Areas affected: Antilles (particularly Dominica), The Bahamas, Florida) and detailed in the article text: 'In Guadeloupe...','In Martinique...','Puerto Rico experienced...'','The storm impacted the Dominican Republic and Haiti...', 'The remnants brought rain to Cuba...' and 'Later, Erika’s remnants dropped locally heavy rainfall across Florida and the Southeastern United States.'

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: 2008 South China floods
Hazards_Annotation: Header: 2008 South China floods, content: 'The 2008 South China floods began on 26 May 2008. Four rounds of torrential rains with landslides and flooding…'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: Areas affected: Sichuan, Guangdong, Jiangxi, Guangxi, Guizhou, Yunnan, Hong Kong.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: 2003 Canberra bushfires, content: 'The 2003 Canberra bushfires caused severe damage to the suburbs and outer areas of Canberra...'
Hazards_Annotation: header: 2003 Canberra bushfires, content: 'The 2003 Canberra bushfires caused severe damage to the suburbs and outer areas of Canberra...'
Time_Annotation: From Info_Box: 'Date(s): 8-21 January 2003'. The article text also refers to 'during 18–22 January 2003'.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: From both the Info_Box ('Location: Canberra, Australian Capital Territory') and article references to 'Canberra, the capital city of Australia'.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Typhoon Olive (1971), content: “Typhoon Olive was an erratic and slightly long-lived tropical cyclone that impacted Japan…”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: “Highest winds: 155 km/h (100 mph)”; Flood from header: Typhoon Olive (1971), content: “The system also caused widespread flooding and landslides through the country…”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Mentioned in Info_Box (Areas affected: Caroline Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Ryukyu Islands, Korea, Japan, South Sakhalin, Kuril Islands) and in the article text (…impacted Japan and affected Manchuria …also caused widespread flooding…in Japan and nearby South Korea…passed near Russian Manchuria…).

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Tropical Storm Delfina ("Severe Tropical Storm Delfina was a damaging tropical cyclone...")
Hazards_Annotation: header: Tropical Storm Delfina ("...Delfina dropped heavy rainfall that caused flooding."); header: Impact and aftermath ("Upon striking Mozambique, Delfina produced strong winds...")
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Tropical Depression Eight (1981), content: "The twelfth tropical cyclone of the annual hurricane season…"
Hazards_Annotation: “Flood” from Header: Tropical Depression Eight (1981), content: "Tropical Depression Eight caused severe flooding in southeastern Texas..."; “Wind” from Header: Impact, content: "The depression spawned 14 tornadoes... a tornado in Galveston... produced a wind gust of 92 mph (148 km/h)."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: Header "2020 East Africa floods" states: "The 2020 East Africa floods were a natural disaster… leading to massive flooding…"
Hazards_Annotation: Header "2020 East Africa floods" from the article indicates the main hazard is flooding: "They began when excessive rains began falling in March, leading to massive flooding…"
Time_Annotation: Info_Box (Date: March-May 2020); article content: “They began when excessive rains began falling in March… The 2020 Long Rains (March–May)…”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Location: Rwanda, Kenya, Somalia, Burundi, Ethiopia, Uganda, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Tanzania); article header-content pair: “The 2020 East Africa floods were a natural disaster in Rwanda, Kenya, Somalia, Burundi, Ethiopia, Uganda, Democratic Republic of Congo, Djibouti and Tanzania.”

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Typhoon Xangsane (2000), content: “Typhoon Xangsane, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Reming, was a typhoon that made landfall in the Philippines and Taiwan.”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind is indicated in Info_Box: “Highest winds: 165 km/h (105 mph)” and in header: Impact, content: “Strong winds and heavy rains occurred in Quezon…”. Heavy rains of 312.3 mm in 24 hours (header: Impact) imply flooding.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Caroline Islands, Philippines, Taiwan, Japan'

Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box: “Type: Flash flood”
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box: “Type: Flash flood”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Typhoon Dot (1985) states 'Typhoon Dot, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Saling, was the strongest storm of the 1985 season,' indicating it is a typhoon (Tropical Storm/Cyclone).
Hazards_Annotation: Wind hazard from Info_Box: 'Highest winds: 280 km/h (175 mph)'; Flood hazard from article content: 'Overall, 42 towns were flooded, forcing a total of 125,000 people to flee their homes.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Philippines, Hainan, Vietnam' (Hainan is part of China), and article references Typhoon Dot affecting the Philippines, Hainan (China), and Vietnam.

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Typhoon Phanfone (2014), content: "Typhoon Phanfone, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Neneng, was a powerful tropical cyclone which affected Japan in early October 2014."
Hazards_Annotation: Wind information in Info_Box: "Highest winds: 250 km/h (155 mph)." Flood information in header: Japan, content: "Throughout Shizuoka Prefecture, 8 buildings were destroyed and a further 1,439 buildings were damaged by flooding."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Mariana Islands, Japan, Alaska.' In 'Preparations and impact' section: 'The extratropical remnant ... brought heavy rains to parts of British Columbia, Canada.'

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Tropical Storm Helene (2000), content: 'Tropical Storm Helene was a long-lived tropical cyclone... It was the twelfth tropical cyclone and eighth tropical storm of the 2000 Atlantic hurricane season.'
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: 'Highest winds: 70 mph (110 km/h)'; Flood from header: Tropical Storm Helene (2000), content: 'After degenerating into a tropical wave, the system produced flooding and mudslides in Puerto Rico... It produced heavy rainfall... The rains flooded hundreds of houses...'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, Hispaniola, Jamaica, Cuba, Isle of Youth, Eastern United States, Atlantic Canada) and Caribbean header content (When Tropical Depression Twelve first formed, several governments across the Lesser Antilles issued a tropical storm watch, including the SSS islands, Antigua and Barbuda, Anguilla, Montserrat, and Saint Kitts and Nevis).

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Cyclone Hollanda, content: “Tropical Cyclone Hollanda was the worst tropical cyclone in Mauritius in 19 years.”
Hazards_Annotation: header: Impact, content: “Ultimately, Cyclone Hollanda made landfall at peak intensity… producing wind gusts… In addition to the winds, the storm dropped torrential rainfall…”
Time_Annotation: Info_Box states: “Formed: 6 February 1994 (1994-02-06), Dissipated: 15 February 1994 (1994-02-15).” The article’s first header also confirms: “It formed on 6 February 1994… The cyclone became extratropical on 14 February.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box states: “Areas affected: Mauritius, Reunion.” In the article, it says: “...striking Mauritius on 10 February... It later passed just southeast of Réunion...”

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Erick (2013), content: “Hurricane Erick brought moderate impacts to the western coastline of Mexico in July 2013, and was the last of a succession of four Category 1 hurricanes to affect the Pacific coast of Mexico...”
Hazards_Annotation: header: Preparations and impact, content: “...the outer rainbands of the storm affected the southwestern coastline with gusty winds... In Guerrero, minor flooding was reported in the cities of Acapulco and Puerto Marques. A river overflowed its banks in Nayarit, flooding several cities...”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Southwestern Mexico, Western Mexico, Baja California Peninsula'; supported by references in article text (e.g., 'the outer bands of the system brought gusty winds and isolated heavy rainfall to Western Mexico').

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Typhoon Phanfone ("Typhoon Phanfone, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ursula, was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone...")
Hazards_Annotation: header: Visayas ("...winds were expected...Severe flooding caused devastating damage in the many provinces...")
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Caroline Islands, Philippines)

Main_Event_Annotation: header: 2014 Southeast Europe floods, content: “Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone […] causing floods and landslides.”
Hazards_Annotation: header: 2014 Southeast Europe floods, content: “Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone […] causing floods and landslides.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Location: Serbia Bosnia and Herzegovina Croatia Romania) and “Affected regions” header (… while Austria, Bulgaria, Hungary, Italy, Poland and Slovakia were affected by the storm.)

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Typhoon Kujira (2009)
Hazards_Annotation: Wind hazard from Info_Box (Highest winds: 215 km/h). Flood hazard from header: Typhoon Kujira (2009), content: “Torrential rains produced by Typhoon Kujira … triggered severe flooding…”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: “Areas affected: Philippines, Russian Far East” (Info_Box)

Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box (Formed: July 19, 2008; Dissipated: July 23, 2008; Highest winds: 65 mph)
Hazards_Annotation: Wind noted in Info_Box (Highest winds: 65 mph) and in the 'Impact' header (buoy recorded gusts to 58 mph); Flood noted in 'Tropical Storm Cristobal (2008)' and 'Impact' headers (minor street and basement flooding in North Carolina and Nova Scotia).
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Florida, The Carolinas, Atlantic Canada); also referenced in article discussing impacts in Florida, the Carolinas (United States), and Nova Scotia (Canada).

Main_Event_Annotation: From header: Tropical Storm Usagi (2018) — “Severe Tropical Storm Usagi, known in the Philippines as Tropical Storm Samuel…”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind: from Info_Box — “Highest winds: 165 km/h (105 mph)”; Flood: from header: Philippines — “Flooding was reported in Iloilo City,” and header: Vietnam — “60 roads were flooded in Ho Chi Minh City.”

Main_Event_Annotation: header: McNally Fire, content: "The McNally Fire was a massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest ..."
Hazards_Annotation: header: McNally Fire, content: "The McNally Fire was a massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest ..."
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Date(s): July 21, 2002 (2002-07-21) -August 29, 2002 (2002-08-29)(40 days)'; header 'McNally Fire' content: 'The fire burned from July 21 to August 29, 2002.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Location: Sequoia National Forest, Tulare County, California'; header 'McNally Fire' content: 'massive wildfire in the Sequoia National Forest ... in July and August 2002 ... largest wildfire of the 2002 California wildfire season.'

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Carrie states 'Hurricane Carrie was the strongest tropical cyclone of the 1957 Atlantic hurricane season.'
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: 'Highest winds: 140 mph (220 km/h)'; Flood from header: Preparations and impact states '...causing strong waves, and severe flooding...'

Main_Event_Annotation: Header 'Tropical Storm Fran (1984)': “Tropical Storm Fran was one of the deadliest tropical cyclones in the history of Cape Verde.”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind: Info_Box, “Highest winds: 65 mph (100 km/h).” Flood: Impacts header, “While passing southeast of Cape Verde, Fran dropped torrential rainfall on the islands, which caused significant flooding.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: From 'Info_Box' (Areas affected: Cape Verde Islands) and article states, “The storm caused no impact outside of Cape Verde.”

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Cerro Grande Fire, content: “The Cerro Grande Fire[1] was a prescribed forest fire in Los Alamos, New Mexico…”
Hazards_Annotation: Header: Cerro Grande Fire, content: “The Cerro Grande Fire…lost their homes in the resulting 43,000-acre (170 km2) fire.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: article header: Cerro Grande Fire, content: 'The Cerro Grande Fire[1] was a prescribed forest fire in Los Alamos, New Mexico, United States of America ...'

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Julia (2010), content: “The twelfth tropical cyclone, fifth hurricane and fourth major hurricane of the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season...”
Hazards_Annotation: header: Preparations and impact, content: “winds reached between 24 and 30 mph...several communities also reported wind damage” and “floods triggered several landslides...”

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Typhoon Agnes (1984) states: 'Typhoon Agnes ... was the fourth final tropical cyclone to affect the Philippines during the 1984 Pacific typhoon season.'
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: 'Highest winds: 220 km/h (140 mph)' and Flood from Header: Vietnam, content: '...the typhoon dropped torrential rains that caused flooding...'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Philippines, Vietnam) and article text indicating the system dissipated over Thailand on November 8.

Main_Event_Annotation: From the header "Cyclone Asani," content: "Severe Cyclonic Storm Asani [...] was a strong tropical cyclone."
Hazards_Annotation: From the header "India": "The cyclone's associated strong wind caused very heavy rain... [and] ... Indian Navy has prepared... flood relief teams...," also "Another man was killed by a lightning strike..."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: India...) and header: Bangladesh

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Hurricane Fred (2015), content: “Hurricane Fred was the easternmost Atlantic hurricane…” confirms it is a hurricane, corresponding to a Tropical Storm/Cyclone event.
Hazards_Annotation: Wind – From Info_Box: “Highest winds: 85 mph (140 km/h)” and Header: Hurricane Fred (2015), content: “…Gale-force winds battered much of the Barlavento region…”; Flood – From Header: Hurricane Fred (2015), content: “…rainstorms flooded homes, washed out roads, and ruined farmland…”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box indicates 'Areas affected: West Africa, Cape Verde'; under the 'West Africa' header, Senegal and Guinea-Bissau are explicitly mentioned as affected by the storm.

Main_Event_Annotation: Mentioned as the “2014 Bulgarian floods” in the header: “2014 Bulgarian floods.”
Hazards_Annotation: Described as severe flash flooding in header: “2014 Bulgarian floods, content: Romania” (‘torrential rains caused severe flash flooding’).
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Elsa, content: “Hurricane Elsa was a deadly and destructive tropical cyclone…”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box (Highest winds: 85 mph). Flood from header: Hurricane Elsa, content: “…caused flash flooding…”. Lightning from header: Other islands, content: “During these storms produced by Elsa, more than 1,000 lightning strikes were recorded within an hour.”
Time_Annotation: From the Info_Box: “Formed: June 30, 2021 … Dissipated: July 10, 2021.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Listed in the Info_Box (Areas affected) and described throughout the article text (e.g. Lesser Antilles, Greater Antilles, United States, Canada, Venezuela, Colombia).

Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Type: Extratropical cyclone' and header 'The January 2008 North American storm complex was a powerful Pacific extratropical cyclone...'
Hazards_Annotation: Wind and Flood: header 'The system was responsible for flooding rains... along with very strong winds'; Blizzard: Info_Box: 'Type: ...Blizzard'
Time_Annotation: Header "January 2008 North American storm complex" states "starting on January 3, 2008." Info_Box indicates "Dissipated: January 22, 2008 (3rd storm dissipated)."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: "Areas affected: Eastern Russia, Alaska, Contiguous United States, Canada, Northern Mexico, Iceland, United Kingdom, Northern Europe, European Russia."

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Hurricane Brenda (1973) — “Hurricane Brenda of August 1973 was the first tropical cyclone on record to make landfall in the Mexican state of Campeche.”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind information cited in Info_Box (Highest winds: 90 mph) and 'Impact and aftermath' header (winds on land gusted up to 112 mph). Flood information cited under 'Impact and aftermath' header (worst flooding in the city in over 25 years).
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Cayman Islands, Mexico)

Main_Event_Annotation: Info_Box: "Type: Series of low pressure systems and cold snap"
Hazards_Annotation: header: "Cold snap and blizzard"
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Formed: 25 January 2008[1] Dissipated: 6 February 2008' and header: 2008 Chinese winter storms, content: '...starting from 25 January 2008, until 6 February 2008.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Hubei, Hunan, Zhejiang, Guizhou, Guangdong, Jiangxi, Guangxi, Fujian, Henan, Shandong, Jiangsu, Anhui, Shanghai, Chongqing, Shanxi, Sichuan' and article header: 2008 Chinese winter storms, content: '...that affected large portions of southern and central China.'

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Manzanita Fire, content: The Manzanita Fire was a wildfire that burned south of the towns of Beaumont and Banning near Highway 79 in Riverside County, California during June 2017.
Hazards_Annotation: Header: Manzanita Fire, content: The Manzanita Fire was a wildfire that burned south of the towns of Beaumont and Banning near Highway 79 in Riverside County, California during June 2017.
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: "Date(s): June 26, 2017 (2017-06-26) - June 30, 2017 (2017-06-30)"; header: Manzanita Fire, content: "The fire was fully contained on Friday, June 30."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: "Location: San Jacinto Mountains, Riverside County, California"; header: Manzanita Fire, content: "The Manzanita Fire was a wildfire that burned…in Riverside County, California…."

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Tropical Storm Kompasu (2021), content: 'Severe Tropical Storm Kompasu, known in the Philippines as Severe Tropical Storm Maring [...] was a very large and deadly tropical cyclone that affected the Philippines, Taiwan, and southeast China.'
Hazards_Annotation: For Wind: header: Hong Kong, content: 'The Hong Kong Observatory (HKO) issued the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal [...] Gale-force winds of over 70 km/h were generally recorded.' For Flood: header: Philippines, content: 'The Department of Public Works and Highways reported that 15 national roads and highways [...] were impassable due to flooding attributed to Maring (Kompasu) and Tropical Depression Nando.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Philippines, Taiwan, South China (particularly Hainan Island), Vietnam, Thailand)

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane How, content: "Hurricane How was the only tropical cyclone to make landfall on the United States in 1951."
Hazards_Annotation: header: Hurricane How, content: "The storm brought heavy rainfall to Florida, causing flooding ... later became a hurricane ... produced strong winds and high tides."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: 'Hurricane Ignacio (2003)' where it is referred to as a hurricane, indicating a tropical cyclone event
Hazards_Annotation: • Wind: Info_Box ('Highest winds: 105 mph') and header content ('Hurricane force winds blew down trees, signs, and power lines…')  • Flood: header content ('The hurricane produced heavy rainfall… which resulted in flooding')  • Lightning: header content ('Over 300 lightning strikes from the remnant moisture was recorded…')
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: From the Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Baja California Peninsula, Sonora, California' (Baja California Peninsula, Sonora in Mexico; California in the United States), and the article mentions flooding in Mexican states like Sinaloa and remnants impacting California in the U.S.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: 1933 Texas tropical storm
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: “Highest winds: 50 mph (85 km/h)”. Flood from “Impact” header: “The storm dropped heavy rainfall ... that caused flooding and road washouts.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Jamaica, Belize, Yucatan Peninsula, South-Central United States' and Impact section describing passage across Jamaica, Belize, the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico, and rainfall in Texas and Louisiana in the United States.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Cyclone Magda, content: “Severe Tropical Cyclone Magda was a relatively small tropical cyclone…”
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box: “Highest winds: 120 km/h (75 mph)” and header: Cyclone Magda, content: “Although the storm made landfall with winds of 130 km/h (81 mph), damage was limited…”
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Formed: 18 January 2010' and 'Dissipated: 24 January 2010'; also from header-content pair: 'The remnants of Magda persisted until 24 January, at which time they dissipated east of Port Hedland.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Western Australia'; also from header: Cyclone Magda: 'brought minor damage to parts of Western Australia in January 2010.'

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: 'Hurricane Cristobal' states that it was a moderately strong Atlantic tropical cyclone ("Hurricane Cristobal was a moderately strong Atlantic tropical cyclone ...").
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box notes "Highest winds: 85 mph (140 km/h)" (wind). In the 'Hurricane Cristobal' content, it states "Widespread flooding and scattered landslides affected the territory" (flood).
Time_Annotation: Info_Box (Formed: August 23, 2014; Dissipated: September 2, 2014), and ‘Hurricane Cristobal’ header content confirming these dates.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Listed in Info_Box (Areas affected: Puerto Rico, Hispaniola, Turks and Caicos Islands, East Coast of the United States, Bermuda, Iceland) and in the article text (mention of the Bahamas, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic under ‘Meteorological history’ and ‘Antilles’).

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Tropical Storm Dujuan (2021), content: “Tropical Storm Dujuan … was a tropical storm…”
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: “Highest winds: 85 km/h (50 mph)”; Flood from header: Tropical Storm Dujuan (2021), content: “floodwater inundated houses in Surigao del Sur, submerging Tandag City…” and “the storm was able to cause flooding in parts of Visayas.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: “Areas affected: Palau, Philippines”

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: Hurricane Earl (2022), content: "Hurricane Earl was a large, long-lived Category 2 hurricane ..."
Hazards_Annotation: Header: Hurricane Earl (2022), content: "Four fatalities were related to Hurricane Earl: two from lightning in Puerto Rico ... The storm struck Newfoundland with hurricane-force winds ... During a 36-hour period on September 10–12 ... overflowing along the Waterford River which led to a large amount of urban flooding."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box states "Areas affected: Puerto Rico, Bermuda, Newfoundland"; the 'Preparations and impacts' section references effects on the East Coast of the United States and mentions rainfall/rough surf in the United Kingdom and Ireland.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Linda (2015), content: "Hurricane Linda was a strong tropical cyclone in September 2015..."
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: "Highest winds: 125 mph (205 km/h)"; Flood from header: Hurricane Linda (2015), content: "...resulted in heavy rains across portions of Mexico and the Southwestern United States...causing flooding..."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: “Areas affected: Sinaloa, Oaxaca, Zacatecas, Revillagigedo Islands, Southwestern United States,” and from the article text stating that it brought heavy rains across portions of Mexico and the Southwestern United States.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: 1775 Newfoundland hurricane ("The 1775 Newfoundland hurricane, also known as the Independence Hurricane...")
Hazards_Annotation: header: North Carolina and Virginia ("In the heavy storm of wind and rain..."); header: Newfoundland ("Ocean levels rose to heights 'scarcely ever known before' and caused great devastation...")
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: North Carolina, Virginia, Newfoundland)

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Iris, content: "Hurricane Iris was a small, but powerful Category 4 hurricane..."
Hazards_Annotation: Info_Box citing "Highest winds: 145 mph" for wind; header: Hurricane Iris, content: "The hurricane caused severe damage—destroying homes, flooding streets..." for flood.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Windward Islands, Hispaniola, Jamaica, Honduras, Belize, Guatemala, Eastern Mexico) and article text (mentions Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Honduras, Belize, Guatemala, and Mexico were affected).

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Hurricane Floyd, content: "Hurricane Floyd was a very powerful Cape Verde hurricane… It was the sixth named storm, fourth hurricane, and third major hurricane in the 1999 Atlantic hurricane season."
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: "Highest winds: 155 mph (250 km/h)"; Flood from header: Hurricane Floyd, content: "The hurricane produced torrential rainfall in Eastern North Carolina… The rains caused widespread flooding over a period of several weeks; nearly every river basin in the eastern part of the state exceeded 500-year flood levels."
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: “Formed: September 7, 1999 … Dissipated: September 19, 1999.” Also under header “Hurricane Floyd” in the article: “…the hurricane formed off the coast of Africa and lasted from September 7 to 19, becoming extratropical after September 17…”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: “Areas affected: Lucayan Archipelago, East Coast of the United States, Atlantic Canada.” Also from the article under “Hurricane Floyd” header: “…which struck the Bahamas and the East Coast of the United States…” and “Early in Floyd’s duration…tropical storm watches for Antigua and Barbuda… Atlantic Canada…”

Main_Event_Annotation: Header: 'Bond Fire', content states: "The Bond Fire was a wildfire that burned 6,686 acres (2,706 ha) ..."
Hazards_Annotation: Header: 'Bond Fire', content states: "The Bond Fire was a wildfire ..."
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: “Date(s): December 2, 2020 (2020-12-02) – December 10, 2020 (2020-12-10)”; Timeline header: “The fire was first reported on December 2, 2020… The fire was fully contained on December 10, 2020.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: “Location: Santiago Canyon, Orange County, California”; Bond Fire header: “The Bond Fire was a wildfire that burned...in the Santiago Canyon area of Orange County, California in December 2020.”

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Cyclone Ernest, content: “Intense Tropical Cyclone Ernest was one of two intense tropical cyclones in the 2004–05 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season.”
Hazards_Annotation: header: Cyclone Ernest, content: “producing widespread flooding and gusty winds” and header: Impact and aftermath, content: “In southern Madagascar, the cyclone produced high winds and heavy rainfall.”
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Formed: January 16, 2005 (2005-01-16)' and 'Dissipated: January 25, 2005 (2005-01-26)'. Also stated under header 'Meteorological history': '...MF declared Ernest extratropical...until the storm dissipated on January 25.'
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: 'Areas affected: Mayotte, Madagascar'. Header 'Impact and aftermath': 'Cyclone Ernest indirectly affected Malawi...' indicating Mayotte, Madagascar, and Malawi were affected.

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Mangum Fire, content: "The Mangum Fire was a wildfire in Kaibab National Forest in Arizona in the United States."
Hazards_Annotation: header: Mangum Fire, content: "The Mangum Fire was a wildfire in Kaibab National Forest in Arizona in the United States."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: header: Mangum Fire, content: The Mangum Fire was a wildfire in Kaibab National Forest in Arizona in the United States.

Main_Event_Annotation: From the article under header: Cyclone Pam ("Severe Tropical Cyclone Pam was the second most intense tropical cyclone...")
Hazards_Annotation: Wind is mentioned in the Info_Box ("Highest winds: 280 km/h (175 mph)"). Flood is mentioned under headers such as Tuvalu ("Between 10 and 11 March, waves...swept across the low-lying islands of Tuvalu") and Solomon Islands ("Early in the Cyclone Pam's development, it produced torrential rains...").
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box (Areas affected: Fiji, Kiribati, Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Vanuatu, New Caledonia, New Zealand)

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Kincade Fire, content: "The Kincade Fire was a wildfire that burned in Sonoma County, California..."
Hazards_Annotation: header: Kincade Fire, content: "The Kincade Fire was a wildfire that burned in Sonoma County, California..."
Time_Annotation: Info_Box: "Date(s): October 23, 2019 (2019-10-23) -November 6, 2019 (2019-11-06)"; Article content: "...The fire started ... on October 23, 2019...fully contained on November 6, 2019."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: "Location: ...Sonoma County, California, United States"; Article content: "The Kincade Fire was a wildfire that burned in Sonoma County, California in the United States."

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Tropical Storm Talas (2017), content: "Severe Tropical Storm Talas was a tropical cyclone that impacted Vietnam during mid July 2017."
Hazards_Annotation: header: Vietnam, content: "The Vietnam's National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting recorded wind gusts up to 100 km/h... During July 17, flooded streets and disrupted train services..."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box: Areas affected: Vietnam, South China, Laos, Thailand, Myanmar

Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box: "Highest winds: 50 mph" and Flood from header: Tropical Storm Fernand (2019) - "Tropical Storm Fernand ... caused severe flooding in northern Mexico..."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box

Main_Event_Annotation: header: Tropical Storm Matthew (2010), content: "Tropical Storm Matthew was a weak but deadly and destructive tropical cyclone..."
Hazards_Annotation: Wind from Info_Box ("Highest winds: 60 mph..."); Flood from header: Tropical Storm Matthew (2010), content: "...torrential rain produced by Matthew triggered widespread flooding..."
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Info_Box states "Areas affected: Venezuela, Central America, Mexico, Jamaica"; Southeastern Caribbean and Venezuela header references Colombia; Preparations section references Costa Rica; Central America, Honduras, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Mexico sections mention those respective countries.
